pages.text: Capsospongia undulata comes from the Middle Cambrian, with fossils found in the Burgess Shale, Canada. It is a small demosponge, growing up to 7 cm in height. Capsospongia has a unique appearance, with an annulated, or ribbed, surface, which themselves are adorned with horizontal ridges, giving it a similar appearance to the unrelated and later Rugose Corals of the Ordovician.
The generic name derives from the Latin words 'capsa', to mean 'boxed'; and 'spongia', to mean 'sponge'. The specific name derives from the Latin word 'undulatus', to mean 'wavy'.
